A criminal conviction does not necessarily prevent you from receiving benefits, including food stamps, Medicaid, Medicare, Social Security or Social Security Disability income.

A good place to start is the Federal Interagency Reentry Council's Reentry MythBusters website. It dispels common myths about what federal benefits a person may qualify for, even if convicted of a felony. Another good resource is the Social Security Administration, which provides information on qualifying and applying for benefits.

It is a common misconception that those who have been incarcerated or have a felony conviction do not qualify for Federal Student Aid. In fact, changes to federal laws have opened up opportunities for those with a criminal history to further their education. Gaining post-secondary education for those returning to the community after incarceration can increase the chances of employment and independence.

Funding

Do I Qualify for Student Loans?

If you are on probation, parole, or living in a halfway house, you may be eligible for federal student aid, including Federal Pell Grants. The Federal Interagency Reentry Council has produced a series of ReEntry Mythbusters fact sheets that focus on common misconceptions about federal laws that affect those formerly incarcerated. The Federal Student Aid page debunks myths associated with qualifying for post-secondary college funding.

In order to apply for Federal Student Aid, the applicant will need to complete an online application. This FAFSA worksheet will help the applicant prepare the necessary information needed prior to completing the online application.

The Federal Student Aid site contains information and resources on how to prepare for post-secondary education, including the types of student aid and loans available, career and college searches, and the student aid application process. Visit the resources below for more information about ways to pay for schooling:

  • Funding Your Education: The Guide to Federal Student Aid (Resources)
  • Other Federal Student Aid Publications

Find Public Education or Education Assistance

The following links offer information on community colleges in North Carolina, including degrees offered, class schedules, workforce continuing education opportunities, distance learning, and licensing and certification requirements for certain career paths.

  • North Carolina Community College Locations and System Offices in Your Community

You should connect with a healthcare professional as soon as possible after release from incarceration. Restoration of Medicaid and Medicare benefits does not occur automatically.

If you are not eligible for Medicaid or Medicare, you can obtain health insurance under the Affordable Care Act (ACA).

Release from detention constitutes a qualifying life event under the ACA and entitles you to apply for health coverage on the Marketplace. Applicants must apply within 60 days of release. Medicaid, Medicare, and the ACA can be applied for all at the same time.

More information is available at https://www.healthcare.gov or call 1-855-733-3711 to schedule an appointment with a Federal Navigator.

The Federal Interagency ReEntry Council offers a helpful resource that dispels common myths about what federal benefits those recently released from incarceration may be able to access.

Returning to your community after a period of incarceration or suffering the consequences of a criminal conviction on your record can be difficult. Fortunately there are people and programs who can help. This site is intended to help you locate resources and assistance in Western North Carolina.

A good place to start is the Federal Interagency Reentry Council’s Reentry MythBusters which dispels common myths about what federal benefits you may be able to access, even if you’ve been convicted of a felony.

On this site you will find information about housing, jobs, public benefits, healthcare, legal issues, reentry support programs and more.

Finding an affordable place to live that is accessible to stores, job opportunities, public transportation and other public services can be a daunting task, but it is critical to your success.

Here are a few important things to know:

  • Spend no more than 30% to 40% of your income on rent.
  • Affordable housing can be limited and go very quickly. Follow up immediately when you hear about opportunities before it’s too late.
  • It’s important to make a good impression when you meet or talk with perspective landlords or roommates. Show up on time, dress neatly, and be polite. First impressions really matter so present your best self.
  • Landlords will check on your credit rating - make sure you know what they will see. You have the right to request your free credit report each year through the FTC website.
  • If you are a Veteran you may qualify for Veterans assistance.
  • Women may qualify for special housing, such as women-only or women with children options.
  • People with certain disabilities may qualify for special assistance or assisted-living housing options.
  • Special assistance may also be available for those who have been in a foster care program or are struggling with addiction.
  • Your specific criminal history can impact the type of housing that is available to you.

Visit the National Resource Reentry Center for general information about housing options. Check the local resources below for services that meet your unique needs.

Let’s get to work and get paid. Getting work takes work. Here are some resources to help you get there.

Some General Tips

  • Tips for Résumés, Job Applications, and Interviews
  • Job Search Tips
  • How to Explain Your Criminal Record to an Employer
  • Article: A Record Does Not Have to be a Deal-Breaker
  • My One-Minute Commercial: How to Sell Yourself to an Employer
  • Sample Résumé
  • Some employers may check your credit history during the hiring process. Know what they will see. You are entitled to a free annual credit report through the FTC website.

Your specific criminal history can have a tremendous impact on your ability to gain employment, get professional licenses, acquire housing, and obtain benefits.

At the same time, there are many myths about what you may or may not be entitled to if you have been convicted of a crime. It is important to know and understand your rights and that laws can change.

This presentation has general information about your rights and opportunities and about restrictions you may face. In addition, the UNC School of Government has created a C-CAT, an online tool to discover specific collateral consequences of criminal convictions.

Expunging a Criminal Conviction

In some cases it is possible to remove (or expunge) prior convictions from your record. The UNC School of Government has prepared an extensive Relief From A Criminal Conviction guide explaining what mechanisms are available under North Carolina Law.

The NC 211 site is an excellent source of information on many different topics. You may also speak with a Referral Specialist directly: call 866-401-6342 or dial 2-1-1 from your phone. The call is free, confidential, and available 24 hours a day.

The Department of Public Safety website provides a searchable database of active service providers by county in North Carolina. Information may be out of date – always call first to confirm the agency address and stated restrictions. The county-specific query page lets you create either short-form or detailed listings of the providers. The listings can be printed from a PDF document.

For Buncombe County, visit the Buncombe County Department of Health & Human Services site and review the benefits section of this presentation
